text:
So what are the
three things that are certain in life in 2024?

Life. [LAUGHTER]  Well, at least we
know two of them--
death and taxes. So these two are universal. [LAUGHS] They never change.
But what is the third thing?  AI startups.

[LAUGHTER] Yeah. You have AI. Correct. Well, I would say the
third thing in 2024

would be AI is actually
changing humanity. So last year, I saw this
article that some law firms

are using generative AI
to draft legal documents. And some startups
even try to use

AI to help clients argue
in court as opposed to using a human attorney.

So here I think it's important
to define what we mean by AI. And I want to use Mark
Riedl's definition.

AI in the context
of this talk refers to algorithms that perform tasks
or behaviors that a person would

reasonably deem to require
intelligence of human to do so. Of course, AI is too
much of an umbrella term.

And in this talk,
I sometimes use it to refer to
nontraditionally AI things.

But for the sake of
simplicity and consistency, I'm just going to use
AI throughout the talk

to refer to a bunch of
these kinds of algorithms. So despite the
promises of AI, I think

there has always been a
gap between what AI can do and how AI can serve humanity.

In the '90s, Rich
Caruana's research project found that doctors
actually prefer

rule-based models over
better-performing neural nets. Does anybody want to know why?

Yes. I guess there's something
to do with explainability. Like with the
rule-based, you can see how the decision was
made, whereas the neural net,

you might not be able
to figure that out. Precisely. That was the case.

So rule-based models
allow the doctor to see the list of rules
AI used to make a diagnosis

or to predict the risk
of pneumonia as opposed to neural nets that
function as a black box.

It doesn't allow any changes or
any correction of AI mistakes. Do you have any idea when
was this paper published?

I think it's the '90s, but the
date was cut off in this image.

You can search for the title. It's published in KDD
if I remember correctly.

Well, this paper--
actually, I was wrong. This paper was probably
published much later, but the project I
mentioned was in the '90s.

So this particular paper is,
I think, it's in the 2000.

All right. So how do we close this gap? I believe by conducting
human-centered design we can

close this gap to some extent. For example, in this project,
I worked with my students

and pathologists
to consider how we can use AI to help them
examine histopathology images.

And there is no shortage of AI
models for pathology these days. Just to give you
some ideas, here are

a bunch of existing startups
working in this space. However, there is
currently a lack

of consensus about the adoption
of AI amongst pathologists because AI as of now is
still not good enough

to completely replace humans. So it's really
unclear then how AI

could fit into a human
pathologist workflow. To tackle this problem, we
conducted human-centered design

field studies with
pathologists from UCLA Health. Our key finding was that
pathologists could work with AI

just like how they work with
their trainee in the way that they can see AI's findings
as if AI as a trainee reporting

back to them. And they serve as the expert
following a top-down workflow

to verify these findings. So here's the user interface we
design based on these insights.

A pathologist would start
by seeing the AI's result. Here it shows a WHO
grade III tumor.

And then they will
see at the top level a number of criteria based on
which the AI model comes up

with these diagnoses. And it shows that mitosis is
the top most important criteria

in this case. And then they can
drill down to one level deeper to see list
of evidences based

on which AI identify
mitotic cells as well as the saliency map to
show that AI is indeed

focusing on the cell but
not some other nonrelevant information.

So they are still unsure. They can pick some of
these sample evidences

and then drill down
to the original slide with full context of the image
to verify that AI is indeed

making the right decision
on this particular part of the image. And along the way, if
they see any mistakes,

they can override
those decisions and the entire diagnosis if
necessary will be updated.

In a study with 12 pathologies
from three medical centers within less than an
hour of training,

they could achieve
more accurate grading using this tool
called xPath compared to an existing digital tool.

I think this project
I just showed you is an example of how
human-centered design can close

the gap between what
pathology AI can do and how this kind
of AI can actually

help pathologists' work. So generally speaking, my
research goal is to develop

interactive systems that can
catalyze AI advances by working

towards three levels of
human-centered objectives-- augmenting human abilities,
assimilating human intents,

and aligning with human values. So next, I would give
you some examples for one

of each of these three levels. For augmenting human
abilities which is actually

the majority of my work
in the past five years, I have explored the space of
medical diagnosis and research,

mechanical and robotic
design, and text reading. So to give you an
example, I want
to focus on the second area-- mechanical and robotic design.

So in this project,
which is actually the last project of my
PhD, so if people ask me,

when did you change your
research from fabrication to AI? So this is the point where I
realized there is something

that's really interesting. So it's called
generative design, even though we're
not really using

generative AI, in particular. So the goal in
this project was we

want to augment
humans' abilities to design both structure
and appearance.

Structure and appearance
are both important but they often
trade off each other in the traditional
mechanical design tasks.

Existing tools often prioritize
structural integrity, but they lack the
interactiveness for users

to explore within the goal
of structural integrity. How can I explore appearances?

To understand this tool
called Forté, let's walk through the process
of using it to design

a leg for a quadruped robot.  To start, the user would
perform some simple sketches

and describe the
loading scenario. So here's the original robotic
leg we want to redesign.

And the user can just
sketch some shapes like this curvy
structure they want

to create the robotic leg of. And then they will also
specify the load, which

is the weight of the
robot's body onto this leg, as well as the bulging
condition, which

is where this robot
leg makes contact with the world on the ground,
as well as the design domain.

You can think of it
as a bounding box that covers the space in
which this leg can take place.

After these simple
sketches and annotations,

next, the user can use
Forté to generate structures based on the sketch.

For example, the
user can ask the tool to add additional support
because the initial sketch might

not be sturdy enough
to support the weight. So here Forté as a parallel
structure next to the user's

original sketch.  Or the user can ask the tool
to create a variation based

on the original sketch. So here it looks a little
bit different but still, the resulting
structures try to stay
similar to the original sketch.

And the last technique
is to consider the sketch as defining a
boundary within which

the optimization can put in more
structures to provide support.

You can think of
these three techniques as incorporating the appearance
information, the sketch

into the optimization
by trying to mimic the user's sketch in
the generative process

of the structures. Importantly, we
need to allow users

to control this generation. So we provide this
global similarity slider.

By increasing the
similarity value, AI would try to stay as close as
possible to the original sketch

versus a lower
value would allow AI to go a little wider
to generate structure

that look more different.  You can see the differences
between two similarities.

And then once a user sees
a result coming back,

they should be able to think
about it and make some edits and the AI should take
into consideration

in the next iteration. So it allow the user
to perform this direct

added onto the AI's
result by erasing certain parts of
the structure which

then prompts the AI to
consider those iterations in the next iteration.

And the user can keep doing
this back and forth until they are happy with the
result, or they

can add more structure if they
see this is probably too empty and they want to add
a truss, and then

the optimization
process would try to incorporate the kinds of
intents in the next iteration.

And importantly, we
need to inform the user

along the way what's the
trade-off because not all kinds of
structures would have the same type of
structural integrity.

So we provide this
visualization view a heatmap that visualizes
the stress distributed

over the structure. And lastly, we can go into
the fabrication process.

In this case, we
used laser cutter and installed the new legs
on the quadruped robot.

All right. So that is the process of
designing the leg as an example of using this tool.

So what's happening
under the hood is this algorithm called
topology optimization that

is based on a well-defined
and well-established method finite element analysis.

The basic idea is that
the process of generating a mechanical structure
is given a design domain,

you need to decide
within this bounding box which elements I want to keep
and which I want to throw away.

You can think of it
as like sculpting. You have a bunch of
material and then you just carve away
those you don't want

and then whatever is left
is what you want to create. So we have a design
domain, in this case, 2D

of these finite elements, xe. And then this entire
domain of elements

will undergo the
optimization process where each iteration tries to
either increase or decrease

each element's density governed
by this objective function until eventually, the
compliance converges.

With minimum
compliance means that with maximum
structural integrity given the limitation
of the material

as well as the user's
sketch to follow. So this FEM method
is already out there.

And we didn't change it at all. We use it as a black box. But the way we enable
these novel interactions

is to tweak whatever comes
out of this black box in each iteration.

So in each iteration,
this black box would spit out for each
element a new value.

And I'm going to go through
some of the approaches that enable the three techniques.

So for adding a new
structure, we simply say, whatever is on the
users' sketch we keep it.

Anything else, we follow what
the objective function says. For obtaining a variation
instead of manipulating

these xe new, we instead
distribute the initial value

when we assign the mass, the
material to the desired domain.

We say the closer the space is
to the original sketch the more initial material we assign.

That steer the
optimization process towards preferring being closer
to the user's original sketch

determined by the
similarity value. And for the last
technique, optimize within,

we simply say, we're going
to expand the user's sketch, and then whatever is on
the boundary we keep it.

Whatever is outside of
it, don't do anything, and whatever inside, follow
the optimization function.

OK. The other interesting thing
I think about this tool

is the users can directly
edit the AI's result. So how do you do that?

Remember we have this design
domain that AI work with. So we also create a mask
of the equal dimension

that represent the user's edit. So for each element
of this mask, we set it to 1 by
default, between 0 and 1

if it's erasing, and at
a value greater than 1 if it's adding new structures. And at each iteration,
we simply apply this mask

to the AI's output
at that iteration. So at the high level,
you can think of it

as steering the optimization
towards resemblance of the user's edits.

Just a quick question. Yes. Why are you doing it as a
multiplication here as opposed to just building it into
the optimization side

function itself or
the loss function? Yeah. The other approach is
to do what you said,

but that involves changing
the FEM method, which we try to avoid in the first place.

And in this way, you
can also think of it as just trying to counterbalance
two objectives back and forth

until eventually it converges. We haven't tried the
approach you said. It could generate equally good
or even better result. [LAUGHS]
Thank you.  All right.

So we ran a user study and
here are the results created by the participants.

So I think the
highlight here is that by using this tool according
to the results here

as well as participants'
feedbacks, they were able to explore the kind
of appearances that were not

possible because other
tools didn't address both the structural
integrity and appearance.

So when using other tools
you're mostly concerned about the structures,
but Forté allows

them to balance these two
considerations using AI.

After publishing this paper
we also open source it and then we let
some CMU designers

use it to create furniture. [CHUCKLES] So if you ever visit
CMU, maybe in UCLA Samueli Hall

you would see this furniture. [CHUCKLES] Now it has
been six, seven years? [LAUGHS] Maybe not.

[LAUGHTER] We didn't use very
good material. [LAUGHS] And it's also
available, Forté, on GitHub.

I try to update it periodically
but unfortunately, I didn't have time recently. The last update was in 2021.

If you're interested, feel free
to download the source code and then play with it.

So Forté takes a
human-centered approach.

While conventional optimization
is often entirely driven by objective function, Forté
augments the user's ability

to design both
appearance and structure by sketching, annotating,
and editing of AI's results.

So I think this direct
editing of AI results is the most important
and interesting feature

because it finds a way to
assimilate the user's editing intents directly into
the optimization process

even without modifying the
objective function per se. So next, I want to
talk a little more

about this problem of
assimilating the user's intents. And I want to switch
gears a little bit

to talk about image generation. So we know human intents could
be either explicit or implicit.

For example, a lot
of the generative AI these days only takes
into explicit intents

mostly as a text prompt. But some intents
actually implicit--

that is, they are not fully
expressed usually or naturally in explicit forms.

For example, if I ask
Stable Diffusion to generate a surprised face,
you can say, yeah,

surprise is an explicit intent. But what kind of surprise
facial features I want

is unclear whether
what they are because I might have some ideas in my
mind but they remain implicit.

They are not specified
in this text prompt. And I probably wouldn't
want to specify it

to that kind of details. So the question
we're interested at is, how we can elicit
user's implicit intents

without the effort or the
unnatural process of specifying

them in a text prompt? When we worked on this problem,
we were not exactly dealing

with diffusion models
or the latest models, we were still working with
generative adversarial networks

or GAN. So for those who
are less familiar, so GAN was a thing [LAUGHS]
before the diffusion

models took over. So it was able to
generate contents from points or noises
in the latent space.

So each point in the latent
space represents, for example, an image. And if you think of it
that way, then a vector

that connects two
points can be considered an editing of this one image to
become another called an editing

direction, such as making the
face appear to be older, aging.

So the question is,
how can the user discover amongst these
large latent space?

Which editing directions
will generate images that match their intents?

So when we started looking
into this question, we found that in the
literature, there

is something called information
foraging theory that's surprisingly relevant. So it was a pretty
old piece of work.

It was this particular
technique that embodies this theory called
scatter/gather, which

was published in 1992, SIGIR. The main idea is that
when you are confronted

with a large collection
of documents, you can first cluster
them into a bunch of--

create a bunch of
clusters, and then you select some clusters that
seem interesting to you

and then you scatter
them into new clusters. And then you repeat
this process so you

see more and more
fine-grained clusters until eventually all these
clusters seem very interesting

altogether to you. So we felt this would
be appropriate to help

us tackle this intent discovery
for again editing directions.

And we developed this
tool called GANzilla. So here the user
would start by seeing

an initial set of clusters. So remember here each
thumbnail is not just an image.

It actually represents a
set of editing directions that change the original image
to the target image to the end

image. So the user might say, these
two sets of editing directions

seem interesting to me because
I see what's inside these two clusters on the right side.

And then I can scatter them
into a new set of clusters to see in a more fine-grained
matter, how these two

clusters added the phases. And then I can repeat
this process over and over until eventually, I can select
the type of editing that really

closely matches my intents. So here's how it
works in motion.

The user can also
change the number of clusters or to get more
images if they are not

happy with the current batch. And then say they select
these two clusters that

interest them the
most, and then they would scatter these into
a new set of clusters,

very similar to the technique
we just saw in the '92 paper. They can also go back
to a previous cluster,

and they can keep
doing this iteratively. And they can also test this,
adding direction on other images

to see how they
generalize and change the strength of applying
the editing direction

and save these edits
for future uses.

So how well does it work? We conducted some evaluations. So here is the
close-ended tasks.

We gave participants some
reference images and asked them. So here are the target images.

Try to use this tool to find
the editing direction that changed the reference
image to the target image.

And the middle bunch were
the participants' work using GANzilla.

You can see they could find a
match amongst the many editing

directions to move the image
from the reference more much closer to the target images.

So we also conducted some
quantitative analysis.

By comparing the
similarities we found that the similarity between
the user-generated image

and the target image
is indeed greater than the similarity between the
reference and the target image,

meaning that what
they have found out using GANzilla
is closer, indeed

closer to the target image
compared to the reference images.

The second task
we did was running some multiround,
36-round comparisons.

In each round, we compare
with 1,000 randomly sampled adding directions
from the latent space.

And amongst these
36 rounds, 33 times we found that the user-generated
images ranked in the top five

in similarity to
the target images.

We also conducted
an open-ended task. So here the participant
will ask to make

the face in the
reference image more followed by a
descriptive keyword.

So each row represents
a descriptive keyword.

So by looking at these
results, could you guess which three keywords
we gave the participants?
Each row is a different keyword.

It looks like the task is more
difficult in the reverse way. [LAUGHTER]

I'm guessing the top row is
more thrilled or something. More thrilled. OK. [LAUGHS]

Yes. Perhaps more surprise? Yes. That one's probably
the most obvious.

[LAUGHS] [MUSIC PLAYING] All right. So the first row
is actually older.

[LAUGHS] Second, happier, and
the last row, more surprised.

All right. So to [CHUCKLES] verify
that, they indeed succeeded to some degree.

We ran some quantitative tests. We found that in terms
of making the face older,

age increases by 10 years. And we did all this analysis
using tools from this paper.

And when it comes to
happy the confidence level increases by 45%, and then
surprise increased by 56.7%.

This proved that they
were indeed moving along this intent of making these
faces older happier and more

surprised. And some other tasks include
using CLIP embeddings to compare

the similarity between
these descriptive keywords as well as the
user-generated images.

So, in particular, we
compare the similarities

between the user's work and the
top 10 amongst 1,000 randomly

generated sampled edits. And then we found that
user-generated images

are more similar to the
free text keywords compared to just randomly
finding directions

from the latent space.  So some of you might be asking,
again, it's so yesterday.

[LAUGHS] Why don't we just
use text-to-image models? Well, I would say it's
still not outdated

this approach, because
GANzilla, our tool, assimilates users' implicit
intents beyond what text prompts

are capable of. And why is that? Because with text problems,
it's hard to describe

the exact facial features
of old, happy, and surprise that you have in mind.

You have to look at the results
and then maybe tweak the prompt

and then try a bunch
of results again until you happen to see one that
matches what you have in mind.

But GANzilla allows
users to discover what matches their intents using
the scatter/gather techniques.

So some of you might
notice a tiny detail

in this figure I used
a few slides ago. It shows that besides
being implicit

there are actually
more challenges in handling human intents. So, for example, as
of November last year

when I asked Midjourney to give
me a successful tech company CEO, oftentimes it will return
predominantly male images.

So why is that? It's actually technically a
problem called entanglement.

It's because the
attributes of CEO and male are entangled for some reasons
in the generative process.

That's why these models are
always generating male CEO

images, even though it didn't
specify that in your prompt.

So entanglement just
shows that there is another problem in using AI.

It causes AI generation to
misalign with human values because I don't
believe any of us

believe that CEOs
should be male. So how do we design
ways for users

to combat this problem
of misalignment? So the next project
precisely tackles this issue.

Yes. These GANs seem like
[INAUDIBLE] these images.

The latent space is usually
very unstructured sometimes. Did you consider something
like variational autoencoders

or something along those lines? [INAUDIBLE] Yeah. We did not, but
that's a good idea.

We probably should have
tried other ways as well, but we primarily focus on
taking the GAN structure as is

and then construct a user
interface to interact with it. So this next project is
also based on GAN model.

Of course, there are
existing approaches to combat the
entanglement issues.

Most of them are
algorithm-driven. For example, InterFaceGAN
requires developers

to predefine disentanglement
rules for each domain and then human annotators to
label large data sets.

So these are great
ideas and they work. But I argue that there
are still problems

of these sorts of
algorithm-driven value alignment approaches. First, it's not possible
to predefine universally

agreed-upon value. For example, what bias means? And secondly, even if you
already have an algorithm-driven

disentanglement
approach working, you cannot guarantee that when
it's shipped to the end users

the model will always generate
bias-free images or other contents, which means that we
need to somehow provide the last

line of defense for the users
to combat entangled bias generation.

So in this project, we work
on a user-driven direction disentanglement
approach for GAN.

So here is the initial images. You can see some clear
entanglement issues.

When adding glasses to these
faces, for some reasons, the generating process is
entangled with gender, male,

and age, old. So for some reasons,
it has some assumptions

that people who wear glasses
are often male and old people.

OK. So as an end user when you
see these results on the UI, what can you do?

So we came up with this idea
called global disentanglement

by end users. So the end user
would sample a bunch of positive, which means with
glasses, and negative, means

without glasses examples. And as they sample
these examples, they can intentionally select
those that are different,

that counter the entanglement
issues like female with glasses, young
people with glasses,

and give these
counter-examples more weights.

So in this process by
providing the examples, this tool is able
to overcome some

of these entanglement issues. So the results have improved. As you can see that now the
gender entanglement is gone,

but the entanglement
is still there.

And then the user just
continue to add more images to combat the age
disentanglement.

So here's the before
and after comparisons.

So besides global,
you can probably imagine there are
some local things to do for disentanglement.

So indeed the user can
say, I want to add glasses. So areas around the eyes are
OK, you can make changes.

But you shouldn't
change the background. So these two types
of masks provide

the users additional constraints
specified to the model.

Yeah. So there's a comparison of
the three kinds of results before global, after
global, and after

global plus local entanglement. OK. So how does it work
under the hood?

So for global
disentanglement, we can visualize the problem
as-- so here's the gray area

is in editing direction. So it's supposed to be parallel
to glasses, but for some reason,

it's in between old and glasses. So we want to rotate this
editing direction more aligned

or more parallel with glasses. So the way we do
that is by using

the user-selected weighted
examples to calculate this vector added to the
original editing direction

to make it less entangled. This blue vector was calculated
from the user's selected

weighted examples.  And for the local
disentanglement,

we look at the features
in the GAN model. So remember the two masks. So one is here is
OK to make changes,

here is not OK to make changes. So we're intersecting
with the filters. So these two masks either
strengthen certain edits

or weaken certain edits to avoid
the local disentanglement-- to avoid local entanglement.

All right. So here are the results by
participants in our study.

We can see that
using this tool they can deal with
entanglement on their own without going through the
algorithm-driven retraining

annotation process. And compared with some existing
algorithm-driven approaches,

you can see the quality
of this entanglement from our participants are
comparable, sometimes even

better, which is encouraging
because it tells us that the value alignment problem
is not just about AI models,

it can also be addressed on
the user interface level.

OK. So far I've talked about
three example projects--

co-designing both
structure and appearance as a way to augment
humans' ability to do mechanical design
via interactive sketching,

[CLEARS THROAT] and
discovering implicit intents based on information
foraging theory,

and then allowing users to
disentangle a biased image generation on the UI.

So this space of human-centered
interactive AI systems

is still pretty nascent to
me, at least the last two

space, intents and values. And I believe there is a lot of
opportunities for future work.

So in the interest
of time, I just want to briefly touch on some
of the directions I'm thinking about in the future
to see if some of you

might have common ideas
or inspirations we can discuss about.

So first for augmenting
human abilities. I believe one of the important
missions for humanity

is to support
scientific discovery. So despite the
tremendous progress

we have seen in
the past 100 years or so, surprisingly, there
is very little changes

in certain scientific
discovery process. So here is kind of a [CHUCKLES]
joke/slash serious example.

I asked ChatGPT to
describe in picture what it's like for
a scientist to work

on drug discovery
between 1923 and 2023. So-- [LAUGHS]
Six Candles. Even the same actor, probably. [LAUGHTER]

Not much has changed, right? [LAUGHS] The tubes,
the lab, the equipment.

But jokes aside, that's
actually the case. There's really not much
significant changes

in the drug discovery
process, which I think is still pretty suboptimal.

It's time and cost-consuming. New drugs to the market usually
cost $1 billion over 14 years,

and that's only guaranteed
10% success rate, and involves lots of manual
work in an iterative multiphase

process. So even though we HCI people
are good with iteration, but their iteration
is really painful.

They will start with 100Ks of
compounds in the first phase to narrow down to
hundreds of hits,

and the second phase to tens of
leads, and then the last phase to narrow down to one or two
developmental candidates,

assuming that the previous
phases are successful. So the question here is, given
some existing AI developments

that try to help
this process, how can we design novel
tools and systems

to catalyze this kind of AI
to actually help accelerate the drug discovery process?

So the topic about
assimilating human intents, I'm thinking about is AI
with a theory of mind.

So a theory of mind is
this idea that we humans have some ways of inferring
each other's mental states.

So the figure here is the
classic false belief test. So the mom asks the child, what
do you think is in the box?

The box label says Smarties. But when the child opens the
box they're actually pencils.

So now someone else enters the
room, the mom asks the child, so what does the person
think is in the box?

So a child who has
developed a theory of mind would think about this problem
from that person's perspective

who doesn't have his own
knowledge about the box actually contains contents other
than the Smarties.

So this ability to think
in other person's shoes is called theory of mind.

So why do we care about this? Because surprisingly
or not surprisingly,

AI these days is
